normalised: Doctor Aisha Khan of A-I-I-M-S Delhi recounts a particularly harrowing shift last week. It began routinely enough, but quickly escalated. “Around seven thirty P-M, we got a call about a major road accident near Dhaula Kuan. Multiple casualties were expected.” She knew it would be a long night.

unnormalised: The first ambulance arrived at 7:45 PM, bringing in 3 patients. The first, a young man named Rakesh, suffered from a severe head injury (GCS score of 8) and needed immediate neurosurgical intervention. Another woman, identified as Priya Sharma, had multiple fractures and was complaining of severe chest pain. Dr. Khan suspected internal bleeding. The third patient seemed relatively stable with only minor lacerations.
normalised: The first ambulance arrived at seven forty five P-M, bringing in three patients. The first, a young man named Rakesh, suffered from a severe head injury (G-C-S score of eight) and needed immediate neurosurgical intervention. Another woman, identified as Priya Sharma, had multiple fractures and was complaining of severe chest pain. Doctor Khan suspected internal bleeding. The third patient seemed relatively stable with only minor lacerations.

unnormalised: “We immediately activated the mass casualty protocol,” Dr. Khan explained. This involved calling in additional doctors and nurses from other departments, and preparing the operating theaters. Blood bank staff were put on high alert for O-negative blood transfusions. Within the next hour, 4 more ambulances arrived, each carrying 2-3 patients. The hospital started resembling a war zone.

unnormalised: One of the most critical moments was when a child, about 5 years old, arrived unconscious. He had a faint pulse and his oxygen saturation was dangerously low at 70%. Dr. Khan, along with a team of pediatricians, worked tirelessly to stabilize him. "We intubated him and started mechanical ventilation. We also administered IV fluids and medications like Adrenaline 1mg to boost his heart rate." Luckily, after what felt like an eternity, his condition started to improve.
normalised: One of the most critical moments was when a child, about five years old, arrived unconscious. He had a faint pulse and his oxygen saturation was dangerously low at seventy percent. Doctor Khan, along with a team of pediatricians, worked tirelessly to stabilize him. "We intubated him and started mechanical ventilation. We also administered I-V fluids and medications like Adrenaline one milligram to boost his heart rate." Luckily, after what felt like an eternity, his condition started to improve.

unnormalised: By 3:00 AM, the rush had subsided. All patients were either stabilized or admitted to the ICU. Dr. Khan, exhausted but relieved, reflected on the night's events. “Emergency medicine is unpredictable. But it’s moments like saving that child’s life that make it all worthwhile. Though, another incident like that and we will be dangerously low on essential meds like Inj. Methylprednisolone 125 mg.”
